On Thu, 6 Nov 2003, Dave Astels wrote:

[from the JUnit Web site:]
> > "Tests need to run against the background of a known set of objects.
> > This set of objects is called a test fixture.
...
> > Pay close attention, class.  The set of objects is the fixture.  The
> > fixture is what you set up.  This is clear and unambiguous English
> > from the authors of JUnit.

> > For that matter, if I google I get
>
> Of what relavance is this?

JB cited what appeared to be a quotation backing his interpretation of
the term.  He appeared to be claiming that it came from the JUnit Web
site.  I was investigating the claim.

> Google aparently limits it's reading to the web.
>
> Page 74-78, "Test-Driven Development: A Practical Guide".

Hmmmm.  Doesn't appear to be the JUnit Web site ...

> "The relationship of subclasses of TestCase and instacne of those
> subclasses is one of the most confusing parts of xUnit.  Each new kind
> of fixture should be in a new subclass of TestCase.  Each new fixture
                       **
> is created in an instance of that subclass, used once, then discarded."
             **
> and further on the same page:

Hoist with your own petard, I would say ;-)

> > Not really.  A TestCase always contains a fixture.  This may or may
> > not be clearly distinguished by putting it in a setUp() method, but
> > it's the set of objects that you are running your test against.
>
> Which is what JB said.. and what I've said, and what Kent's said...
> and many others as well.  The TestCase subclass is what defines a
> fixture.  setUp() just provides a tidy way of implementing that.
>
> > If we are going to be truly nitpicking,
>
> Oh, lets... I feel the need to be lectured in OO basics.
>
> > then recall that an object is an INSTANCE of a class.
>
> Well... not always... in the common-place OO languages, sure.  But
> sometimes it's a copy of a prototype.

My friend, this is the JUnit list.  We are talking about Java classes.
You may disparage Java as a commonplace OO language.  That's your right.
But in Java:

> > A set of objects can never be a class.
>
> Um.. well... I sort of disagree.  What exactly is a class?  It's the
> describtion of a set of objects.

In Java a class is a very well-specified thing, and it not the same
thing as a instance.  You really ought to know this.  Objects are
instantiated from classes using a well-defined set of operations, and
given an object you can get back to its class.  But they aren't the
same thing, any more than a fixture is a TestCase or testing is the
same as test-driven development.

> > It is  a set of instances of a set of classes.
>
> which (in cool OOPLs anyway) are in turn instances of metaclasses ;-)

But we, alas, are condemned to toil in the uncool world of Java and JUnit,
where we have to make things work.

> > My apologies to the wider world for starting this absurd thread
>
> No thread that stirs up dissention and discussion is absurd.  You
> would prefer that we all sit around typing mediocre rubbish and
> sedately nodding at each other?

I think that that we could use our time more productively than this.

I have been trying to decide whether unit testing is really applicable
in multi-threaded applications, for example, and wondering how JUnit
could be extended to be useful in this area.  What I have seen so far
along these lines is most unsatisfactory.
